title: American_Top_40_1981_October_17th
description:
"You're hearing the hottest hits in the USA from Jamestown, California, to James Creek, Pennsylvania; from Jamesport, Missouri, to Jamesburg, New Jersey, and here's Rick James, up two notches to seventeen with 'Super Freak.'"


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This is a recording of a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this broadcast:

Casey plays a portion of the first hit song ever to come from a motion picture; a song that sold two million records in 1928.

The family act with the most top 40 hits in the rock era (31 songs) has a song in the countdown.

A listener prompted by the title of  Juice Newton's song "Queen Of Hearts" (at number 26) wants to know if any other song titles with the names of playing cards have been hits. Casey tells us about six such songs. Add to that list the 1986 hit, "Two Of Hearts" by Stacy Q.

"For the decade of the 70's, what was the number one soul song and what was the number one country song?" Casey says the soul song was Al Green's first #1 while the country song was Charlie Rich's first #1.

One song in the top ten holds the record for most consecutive weeks, not at number one or number two, but for spending six weeks at number three.

A movie theme song replaces another movie theme song in the number one spot, something Casey says has happened only one other time (in 1977 when "You Light Up My Life" replaced the theme from "Star Wars" but the "Star Wars" song was by Meco and was not in the movie).
